title: Solidarity, Sovereignty, and Sanctuary on the Seas: A Global History of Boat Refugees since the 1940s
descriptions: This grant proposal seeks funding for a research project focusing on the experiences of boat refugees across different time periods and geographic regions. The project will explore the themes of solidarity, sovereignty, and sanctuary as they relate to the journeys of boat refugees, drawing on historical examples such as Jewish boat refugees in the 1940s and Vietnamese boat people in the 1970s and 1980s. The central research question guiding this project is how these notions influenced the experience and reception of boat refugees. The research team will also investigate who hindered and who helped boat refugees on their journeys, and why. The project will examine whether there was solidarity among boat refugees, whether they received help from non-state actors such as merchant vessels and NGOs, how states responded to them at sea, and whether they were able to find sanctuary after their journey. This project aims to break new ground by focusing on the role of the sea, looking beyond the state, and comparing the experiences of boat refugees across different contexts. The research will be based on interviews with boat refugees and other actors, oral history, archival sources, legal cases, and media coverage. Through this interdisciplinary approach, the project will contribute to a deeper understanding of the challenges faced by boat refugees and the responses they receive from various actors.
